lines.code: # The search() and match() functions work on Text, Sentence and Word objects (see pattern.text.tree),
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # i.e., the parse tree including part-of-speech tags and phrase chunk tags.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # The pattern.text.search Match object will contain matched Word objects,
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # emulated with the following classes if the original input was a plain string:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ A list of sentences, where each sentence is separated by a period.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: list.__init__(self, (Sentence(s + ".", token) for s in string.split(".")))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ A list of words, where punctuation marks are split from words.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: list.__init__(self, (Word(self, w, index=i) for i, w in enumerate(s)))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ A word with a position in a sentence.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: self.sentence, self.string, self.tag, self.index = sentence, string, tag, index
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ Returns True if the pattern matches the given word string.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: The pattern can include a wildcard (*front, back*, *both*, in*side),
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: or it can be a compiled regular expression.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if p[:1] == WILDCARD and (p[-1:] == WILDCARD and p[1:-1] in string or string.endswith(p[1:])):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if p[-1:] == WILDCARD and not p[-2:-1] == "\\" and string.startswith(p[:-1]):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # For performance, calling isinstance() last is 10% faster for plain strings.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Search patterns can contain optional constraints,
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # so we need to find all possible variations of a pattern.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Returns a list copy in which each item occurs only once (in-order).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return [x for x in iterable if x not in seen and not seen.add(x)]
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Returns the first item in the list for which function(item) is True, None otherwise.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: for iterable in map(tuple, args) * kwargs.get("repeat", 1):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: p = [x + [y] for x in p for y in iterable]
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Returns all possible variations of a sequence with optional items.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # For example: variations(["A?", "B?", "C"], optional=lambda s: s.endswith("?"))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # defines a sequence where constraint A and B are optional:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Create a boolean sequence where True means optional:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Find all permutations of the boolean sequence:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # [True, False, True], [True, False, False], [False, False, True], [False, False, False].
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Map to sequences of constraints whose index in the boolean sequence yields True.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: for p in product([False, True], repeat=sum(o)):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: v = [b and (b and p.pop(0)) for b in o]
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: v = tuple(iterable[i] for i in xrange(len(v)) if not v[i])
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return sorted(a, cmp=lambda x, y: len(y) - len(x))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # A taxonomy is based on an ordered dictionary
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # (i.e., if a taxonomy term has multiple parents, the most recent parent is the default).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ A dictionary with ordered keys (first-in last-out).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return cls((k, v) for k in keys)
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Adds a new item from the given (key, value)-tuple.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: If the key exists, pushes the updated item to the head of the dict.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: k=self._o[-1] if self._o else None; return (k, self.pop(k))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return "{%s}" % ", ".join("%s: %s" % (repr(k), repr(v)) for k, v in self.items())
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Hierarchical tree of words classified by semantic type.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: For example: "rose" and "daffodil" can be classified as "flower":
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Taxonomy terms can be used in a Pattern:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: FLOWER will match "flower" as well as "rose" and "daffodil".
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: The taxonomy is case insensitive by default.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: return not self.case_sensitive and term.lower() or term
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Check if the term is in the dictionary.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the term is not in the dictionary, check the classifiers.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ Appends the given term to the taxonomy and tags it as the given type.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Optionally, a disambiguation value can be supplied.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ Returns the (most recently added) semantic type for the given term ("many" => "quantity").
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If the term is not in the dictionary, try Taxonomy.classifiers.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the term is not in the dictionary, check the classifiers.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Returns the first term in the list returned by a classifier.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # **kwargs are useful if the classifier requests extra information,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ Returns a list of all semantic types for the given term.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If recursive=True, traverses parents up to the root.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if term in visited: # Break on cyclic relations.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: for w in a: a += dfs(w, recursive, visited, **kwargs)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ Returns all terms of the given semantic type: "quantity" => ["many", "lot", "few", ...]
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If recursive=True, traverses children down to the leaves.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if term in visited: # Break on cyclic relations.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: for w in a: a += dfs(w, recursive, visited, **kwargs)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ Returns the value of the given term ("many" => "50-200")
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: def __init__(self, parents=lambda term: [], children=lambda term: [], value=lambda term: None):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ A classifier uses a rule-based approach to enrich the taxonomy, for example:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: c = Classifier(parents=lambda term: term.endswith("ness") and ["quality"] or [])
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: This tags any word ending in -ness as "quality".
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: This is much shorter than manually adding "roughness", "sharpness", ...
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Other examples of useful classifiers: calling en.wordnet.Synset.hyponyms() or en.number().
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Classifier(parents=lambda word, chunk=None: chunk=="VP" and [ACTION] or [])
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: return [w.synonyms[0] for w in self.wordnet.synsets(word, pos[:2])[0].hyponyms()]
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return [w.synonyms[0] for w in self.wordnet.synsets(word, pos[:2])[0].hypernyms()]
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Allowed chunk, role and part-of-speech tags (Penn Treebank II):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: has_alpha = lambda string: ALPHA.match(string) is not None
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: def __init__(self, words=[], tags=[], chunks=[], roles=[], taxa=[], optional=False, multiple=False, first=False, taxonomy=TAXONOMY, exclude=None, custom=None):
lines.author: anthony@renttherunway.com

lines.code: """ A range of words, tags and taxonomy terms that matches certain words in a sentence.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Constraint.fromstring("QUANTITY|QUALITY") matches quantity-type and quality-type taxa.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: self.chunks   = list(chunks) # Allowed chunk types (NP, VP, ...)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: self.roles    = list(roles)  # Allowed chunk roles (SBJ, OBJ, ...)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: self.exclude  = exclude      # Constraint of words that are *not* allowed, or None.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: self.custom   = custom       # Custom function(Word) returns True if word matches constraint.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Returns a new Constraint from the given string.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Uppercase words indicate either a tag ("NN", "JJ", "VP")
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: [ defines a constraint with spaces, e.g., "[Mac OS X | Windows Vista]".
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: ! can be used as a word prefix to disallow it.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: * can be used as a wildcard character, e.g., "soft*|JJ*".
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: ? as a suffix defines a constraint that is optional, e.g., "JJ?".
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: + as a suffix defines a constraint that can span multiple words, e.g., "JJ+".
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: ^ as a prefix defines a constraint that can only match the first word.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: These characters need to be escaped if used as content: "\(".
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Wrapping order of control characters is ignored:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if v.startswith("!") and self.exclude is None:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: elif v in self.taxonomy or has_alpha(v):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Uppercase words indicate tags or taxonomy terms.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # However, this also matches "*" or "?" or "0.25".
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Unless such punctuation is defined in the taxonomy, it is added to Range.words.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: """ Return True if the given Word is part of the constraint:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: - the word (or lemma) occurs in Constraint.words, OR
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: - the word (or lemma) occurs in Constraint.taxa taxonomy tree, AND
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: - the word and/or chunk tags match those defined in the constraint.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Individual terms in Constraint.words or the taxonomy can contain wildcards (*).
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Some part-of-speech-tags can also contain wildcards: NN*, VB*, JJ*, RB*
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If the given word contains spaces (e.g., proper noun),
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: the entire chunk will also be compared.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: matches the word "Mac" if the word occurs in a Chunk("Mac OS X 10.5").
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the constraint has a custom function it must return True.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if self.custom is not None and self.custom(word) is False:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # If the constraint can only match the first word, Word.index must be 0.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the constraint defines excluded options, Word can not match any of these.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the constraint defines allowed tags, Word.tag needs to match one of these.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if find(lambda w: _match(word.tag, w), self.tags) is None:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the constraint defines allowed chunks, Word.chunk.tag needs to match one of these.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: ch = word.chunk and word.chunk.tag or None
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if find(lambda w: _match(ch, w), self.chunks) is None:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the constraint defines allowed role, Word.chunk.tag needs to match one of these.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: R = word.chunk and [r2 for r1, r2 in word.chunk.relations] or []
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if find(lambda w: w in R, self.roles) is None:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the constraint defines allowed words,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Word.string.lower() OR Word.lemma needs to match one of these.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: b = True # b==True when word in constraint (or Constraints.words=[]).
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the constraint has a word with spaces (e.g., a proper noun),
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # compare it to the entire chunk.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if " " in w and (s1 in w or s2 and s2 in w or "*" in w):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: s1 = word.chunk and word.chunk.string.lower() or s1
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: s2 = word.chunk and " ".join([x or "" for x in word.chunk.lemmata]) or s2
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Compare the word to the allowed words (which can contain wildcards).
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Compare the word lemma to the allowed words, e.g.,
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # if "was" is not in the constraint, perhaps "be" is, which is a good match.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # If the constraint defines allowed taxonomy terms,
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # and the given word did not match an allowed word, traverse the taxonomy.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # The search goes up from the given word to its parents in the taxonomy.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # This is faster than traversing all the children of terms in Constraint.taxa.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # 1) Wildcards in the taxonomy are not detected (use classifiers instead),
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # 2) Classifier.children() has no effect, only Classifier.parent().
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if self.taxa and (not self.words or (self.words and not b)):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: word.chunk and word.chunk.string or None, # "army ants"
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: word.chunk and " ".join([x or "" for x in word.chunk.lemmata]) or None): # "army ant"
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Compare ancestors of the word to each term in Constraint.taxa.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if find(lambda s: p==s, self.taxa): # No wildcards.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: a = self.words + self.tags + self.chunks + self.roles + [w.upper() for w in self.taxa]
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: self.first and "^" or "", "|".join(a), self.multiple and "+" or "")
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ A sequence of constraints that matches certain phrases in a sentence.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: The given list of Constraint objects can contain nested lists (groups).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Parse nested lists and tuples from the sequence into groups.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # [DT [JJ NN]] => Match.group(1) will yield the JJ NN sequences.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # There are two search modes: STRICT and GREEDY.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - In STRICT, "rabbit" matches only the string "rabbit".
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - In GREEDY, "rabbit|NN" matches the string "rabbit" tagged "NN".
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - In GREEDY, "rabbit" matches "the big white rabbit" (the entire chunk is a match).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - Pattern.greedy(chunk, constraint) determines (True/False) if a chunk is a match.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: self.strict = kwargs.get("strict", STRICT in args and not GREEDY in args)
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: self.greedy = kwargs.get("greedy", lambda chunk, constraint: True)
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Returns a new Pattern from the given string.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Constraints are separated by a space.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If a constraint contains a space, it must be wrapped in [].
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Spaces in a range encapsulated in square brackets are encoded.

lines.code: def _match(self, sequence, sentence, start=0, i=0, w0=None, map=None, d=0):
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: #   map : a dictionary of (Word index, Constraint) items.

lines.code: # XXX - We can probably rewrite all of this using (faster) regular expressions.

lines.code: # - "cat" matches "the big cat" if "cat" is head of the chunk.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - "Tom" matches "Tom the cat" if "Tom" is head of the chunk.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - This behavior is ignored with POS-tag constraints:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: #   "Tom|NN" can only match single words, not chunks.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - This is also True for negated POS-tags (e.g., !NN).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.author: tom@organisms.be
